revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox person | image = Sandi Toksvig in 2009.jpg | name = Sandi Toksvig | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100|OBE}} | caption = Sandi Toksvig in 2009 | birth_name = Sandra Birgitte Toksvig | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|5|3|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] | citizenship = [[United Kingdom|British]] (from 2013) | alma_mater = [[Girton College, Cambridge]] | parents = [[Claus Toksvig]]{{cite web|url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=xxUQIHdkk0koDBTrSGpSig&scan=1|title=Index entry|accessdate=5 August 2015|work=FreeBMD. Marriage registered Q2 1954 in Surrey, England|publisher=ONS}}
Julie Anne Toksvig (née Brett) | occupation = Comedian, author, radio and television presenter, co-founder of [[Women's Equality Party]] | party = [[Women's Equality Party]] | spouse = {{marriage|Debbie Toksvig|2014}} | children = 3 }} '''Sandra Birgitte "Sandi" Toksvig''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|OBE}} ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|t|ɒ|k|s|v|ɪ|ɡ}}, {{IPA-da|ˌsandi ˈtʌɡsviːˀ}}; born 3 May 1958){{Cite journal|date=2007-12-01|title=Toksvig, Sandra Birgitte, (Sandi), (born 3 May 1958), writer and comedian|url=https://doi.org/10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.37818|journal=Who's Who|language=en|publisher=Oxford University Press|doi=10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.37818}} is a [[British people|British]]-[[Danes|Danish]] comedian, writer, actor, presenter and producer on British radio and television, and political activist. On 21 October 2016, Toksvig took over from [[Stephen Fry]] as host of the BBC television quiz show ''[[QI]]''. She was the host of ''[[The News Quiz]]'' on [[BBC Radio 4]] from 2006 until June 2015. She also presented the quiz show ''[[1001 Things You Should Know]]'' on [[Channel 4]] television in 2012–13, and began hosting a revived series of the same channel's game show ''[[Fifteen to One]]'' on 5 April 2014. She is joint founder of the [[Women's Equality Party]] (established in March 2015), was installed as [[Chancellor (education)|Chancellor]] of the [[University of Portsmouth]] in October 2012, and is the current president of the [[Women of the Year Lunch]]. On 16 March 2017, Toksvig was announced as the new co-presenter of ''[[The Great British Bake Off]]'', alongside comedian [[Noel Fielding]].{{cite news | last = Ross | first = Alice | title = Noel Fielding and Sandi Toksvig to host new Great British Bake Off | pages = | newspaper = The Guardian | location = London | date = 16 March 2017 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/mar/16/noel-fielding-and-sandi-toksvig-to-host-new-great-british-bake-off}} ==Early life== Toksvig was born in Denmark. Her father, [[Claus Toksvig]], was a Danish journalist, broadcaster, and foreign correspondent, so Toksvig spent most of her youth outside Denmark, mostly in New York City. Her mother, Julie Anne Toksvig (''[[née]]'' Brett), is British.{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/13127990.Sandi_Toksvig_minds_her_manners/|first=Rebecca|last=McQuillan|title=Sandi Toksvig minds her manners |work = The Herald Scotland |date=18 October 2013 |accessdate=26 January 2016}} She attended [[Tormead School]], an independent girls' school near [[Guildford]], when her father was based in London. Her first job was a position as a [[follow spot]] operator for the musical ''[[Jesus Christ Superstar]]'' at the age of 18.{{cite book|last=Toksvig|first=Sandi|date=24 January 2013|title=The Chain Of Curiosity |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=guobYpUxBj8C&pg=PT113&lpg=PT113&dq=sandi+toksvig+jesus+christ+superstar&source=bl&ots=R6ZFFDWvvG&sig=l1aiuxxTn6QYrJabmmYYh9pqnio&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-4haU7SgG6Gv7AaYzIDAAQ&ved=0CGMQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=sandi%20toksvig%20jesus%20christ%20superstar&f=false|location=London, UK|publisher=[[Hachette (publisher)|Hachette UK]]|isbn=9781405527231|accessdate=25 April 2014}}{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/3670221/Sandi-Toksvig-All-the-worlds-backstage.html|title=Sandi Toksvig: All the world's backstage|last1=Tokvsig |first1=Sandi |date=30 December 2007 |work= [[The Sunday Telegraph]] |accessdate=25 April 2014}} She read law, archaeology and anthropology at [[Girton College, Cambridge]], graduating with a [[first-class degree]] and receiving two prizes for outstanding achievement (The Raemakers and the Theresa Montefiore Awards).{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2012/jan/23/sandi-toksvig-chancellor-portsmouth-university|title=Sandi Toksvig becomes chancellor of Portsmouth University|last=Press Association|date=23 January 2012|work=The Guardian|accessdate=31 December 2013}} One of her law tutors was [[Lord Denning]].{{cite web|url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/guide/tv/qi/episodes/9/8/|title=QI – Series I – Inequality – British Comedy Guide|publisher=comedy.co.uk|accessdate=13 April 2015}} ==Career== {{Quote box |quote=When I see comedian—and ‘comedienne’, of course I hate it—I think ‘Oh, really?’ because I think of myself as a writer and broadcaster. Sometimes it's funny but I’ve just done a piece for [[BBC Radio 3|Radio 3]] all about [[Mary Wollstonecraft]], and there's not a joke in it. |source=''[[The Times]]''|width=25em |bgcolor=#FFFFF0 |quoted=true |salign=center}} [[File:Toksvig 2008.jpg|thumb|right|Toksvig performing in 2008]] ===Beginnings=== Toksvig began her comedy career at Girton College, [[Cambridge University]], where she wrote and performed in the first all-woman show at the [[Footlights]]. She was there at the same time as fellow members [[Stephen Fry]], [[Hugh Laurie]], [[Tony Slattery]], and [[Emma Thompson]], and wrote additional material for the [[Perrier award]]-winning [[Cambridge Footlights Revue|Footlights Revue]]. She was also a member of the university's [[Cambridge University Light Entertainment Society|Light Entertainment Society]]. She started her television career on [[children's television|children's series]], presenting ''[[No. 73]]'' (1982–1986), the ''Sandwich Quiz'',{{cite web |url=http://www.vivienneclore.com/artist-details/sandi-toksvig/ |title=Artist Management |publisher=Vivienne Clore |date= |accessdate=16 March 2012}} ''[[The Saturday Starship]]'', ''[[Motormouth]]'', ''[[Gilbert the Alien|Gilbert's Fridge]]'', and on factual programmes such as ''Island Race'' and ''The Talking Show'', produced by [[Open Media]] for [[Channel 4]]. In October 2012, in the wake of allegations about the behaviour of [[Jimmy Savile#Allegations of sexual abuse|Jimmy Savile]], and claims that during the 1960s, 1970s, and 1980s, there was a culture within the BBC which [[Criticism of the BBC#Jimmy Savile sexual abuse allegations|tolerated sexual harassment]], she says she was groped by a "famous individual" on air in the 1980s.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-19861688 |title=Sandi Toksvig claims she was groped while broadcasting |date=7 October 2012 |work=[[BBC News Online]] |accessdate=9 October 2012}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/oct/07/sandi-toksvig-i-was-groped-on-air |title=Sandi Toksvig: 'I was groped on air in the 1980s' |date=7 October 2012 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=9 October 2012 }} Toksvig said the allegations of inappropriate behaviour at the BBC "did not surprise me at all". ===Comedy=== In the comedy circuit, Toksvig performed at the first night of the [[The Comedy Store, London|Comedy Store]] in [[London]], and was once part of [[The Comedy Store Players|their Players]], an [[improvisational comedy]] team.[http://www.comedystoreplayers.com/history.html Comedy Store Players Official Site – History] -retrieved on 16 May 2008 In television, she appeared as a panellist in comedy shows such as ''[[Call My Bluff (UK game show)|Call My Bluff]]'' (a regular as a team captain), ''[[Whose Line Is It Anyway? (UK TV series)|Whose Line Is It Anyway?]]'', ''[[Mock the Week]]'', ''[[QI]]'', and ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', where she appeared on the very first episode in 1990.[http://www.tv.com/have-i-got-news-for-you/show/2627/episode_listings.html?season=1&tag=nav_bar;1 Have I Got News For You episode guide] at TV.com — retrieved on 16 May 2008 She was also the host of ''[[What the Dickens]]'', a [[Sky Arts]] [[quiz show]]. On radio, she is a familiar voice for BBC Radio 4 listeners, having appeared on ''[[I'm Sorry I Haven't a Clue]]'', [[The Unbelievable Truth (radio show)|''The Unbelievable Truth'']], and as the chair of ''[[The News Quiz]]'', where she replaced [[Simon Hoggart]] in September 2006, but left in June 2015 in order to enter politics to champion women's rights. Her final show was first broadcast on 26 June. She presented Radio 4's travel programme ''Excess Baggage'' until it was axed in 2012. {{cite news|url=http://www.wanderlust.co.uk/magazine/news/bbc-radio-4s-excess-baggage-decommissioned|first=|last=|title=Radio 4's Excess Baggage to be axed|work=Wanderlust|date=2012-03-20|accessdate=2016-01-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202101608/http://www.wanderlust.co.uk/magazine/news/bbc-radio-4s-excess-baggage-decommissioned|archivedate=2 February 2016|df=dmy-all}} ===Drama and factual=== In 1993, Toksvig wrote a musical, ''Big Night Out at the Little Sands Picture Palace'', for [[Nottingham Playhouse]], co-starring with [[Anita Dobson]] and [[Una Stubbs]]. In 2002, it was re-written, with [[Dilly Keane]], for the [[Watford#Watford Palace Theatre|Watford Palace Theatre]], in which they appeared with [[Bonnie Langford]].[http://www.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=207&story=E8821025025538 Review of ''Big Night Out'' in What's On Stage] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616055325/http://www.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=207&story=E8821025025538 |date=16 June 2011 }}; retrieved 23 February 2009. Toksvig and Elly Brewer wrote a Shakespeare deconstruction, ''The Pocket Dream'', which Toksvig performed at the [[Nottingham Playhouse]] and which transferred to the [[West End theatre|West End]] for a short run. The pair also wrote the 1992 TV series ''[[The Big One (TV series)|The Big One]]'', in which she also starred. She has appeared in a number of stage plays, including ''[[Androcles and the Lion (play)|Androcles and the Lion]]'', ''[[Much Ado About Nothing]]'', and ''[[The Comedy of Errors]]''. In 1996, she narrated the ''Dragons!'' interactive CD-ROM published by Oxford University Press and developed by Inner Workings, along with [[Harry Enfield]].{{cite web | title = Television graphics around the world | url = http://www.meldrum.co.uk/mhp/testcard/around_world.html | website = meldrum.co.uk | date = 29 March 2000 | access-date = 26 April 2013 }} The software was primarily aimed at children and featured songs and poems about dragons. She also narrated the ''Winnie the Witch'' CD-ROM. She appeared in the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' audio drama ''[[Red (Doctor Who audio)|Red]]'' by [[Big Finish Productions]], released in August 2006. In December 2006, she hosted and sang at the [[London Gay Men's Chorus]] sold-out Christmas show, ''Make the Yuletide Gay'', at the [[Barbican Arts Centre|Barbican Centre]].{{cite web|url=http://www.barbican.org.uk/music/event-detail.asp?ID=4705|first=|last=|title=Music Event Detail|work=|date=|accessdate=2016-01-26}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Over Christmas and New Year 2007/2008, she narrated the [[pantomime]] ''Cinderella'' at the [[Old Vic Theatre]]. In October 2011, she narrated the new musical ''[[Soho Cinders]]'' at the [[Queen's Theatre]], London. In 2011 she hosted a second season of [[BBC Two]]'s ''Antiques Master''. Toksvig wrote a play entitled ''[[Bully Boy]]'' which focused on [[post-traumatic stress]] among British servicemen. The play premièred at the [[University of Southampton#Highfield Campus|Nuffield Theatre]] in Southampton in May 2011, and starred [[Anthony Andrews]].{{cite web|title=Sandi Toksvig on Bully Boy|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/brighton-theatre/news/05-2011/sandi-toksvig-on-bully-boy_8993.html|website=WhatsOnStage|accessdate=17 March 2017}} The play then launched the debut season of [[The Other Palace|St James Theatre]] in September 2012, the first new West End theatre to open in 30 years.{{cite web|title=St James Theatre in London's West End opens|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-19636447|website=BBC News|accessdate=17 March 2017}} In the 2013 Christmas Special of BBC's ''[[Call the Midwife]]'', Toksvig made a cameo appearance as grumpy ward nurse Sister Gibbs.{{cite news | last = O'Donovan | first = Gerard |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/tv-and-radio-reviews/10531223/Call-the-Midwife-Christmas-special-review.html |title=''Call the Midwife'', Christmas special, review |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=25 December 2013 |accessdate=31 December 2013}}{{cite news | last = Walker-Arnott | first = Ellie |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2013-12-04/call-the-midwife-christmas-special---first-look-preview |title=''Call the Midwife'' Christmas special — first look preview |work=[[Radio Times]] |date=14 December 2013 |accessdate=31 December 2013 }} Toksvig was appointed [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in the [[2014 New Year Honours]] for services to broadcasting.{{London Gazette|issue=60728 |supp=y|page=14|date=31 December 2013}} On 28 April 2015, it was announced that Toksvig would leave BBC Radio 4's ''The News Quiz'' in June at the end of the 28th series, which was scheduled to begin on 15 May of that year. She said: "I have decided it is time to move on and, of course, I feel sad but I think it's the right moment. The show is in great shape and, like a good house guest, you should always depart when people still wish you'd stay a bit longer." The BBC said Toksvig had made the "difficult decision" to leave in order "to embark on a new and exciting stage of her career".{{cite news |title= Sandi Toksvig steps down from Radio 4's ''News Quiz'' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-32495153 |author= |date= 28 April 2015 |work=[[BBC News Online]] | publisher = BBC |accessdate=12 May 2015}} On 30 April 2015, Toksvig announced that her decision to quit ''The News Quiz'' had been made in order to allow her to help set up a new political party named the [[Women's Equality Party]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/apr/30/sandi-toksvig-quit-radio-4-news-quiz-set-up-womens-rights-political-party |title=Sandi Toksvig reveals she quit Radio 4 to set up women's rights political party |last1=Topping |first1=Alexandra |date=30 April 2015 |work=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=30 April 2015}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/bbc/11574333/Sandi-Toksvig-quit-The-News-Quiz-for-Womens-Equality-Party.html|title=Sandi Toksvig quit ''The News Quiz'' for Women's Equality Party |first=Hannah |last=Furness |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=30 April 2015 |accessdate=3 May 2015 }} In November 2015, Toksvig was a guest of [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[Desert Island Discs]]''. Her choices included [[Joe Nichols]] ("[[What's a Guy Gotta Do]]"), [[Gustav Winckler]], [[The Weather Girls]], [[Barbra Streisand]], and [[Bonnie Langford]]. Her book choice was ''[[The Ashley Book of Knots]]'', and her luxury item was an endless supply of the ''[[Daily Mail]]''.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b06qg1ls |title=BBC Radio 4 – Desert Island Discs, Sandi Toksvig |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=29 November 2015|accessdate=4 December 2015}} Her most recent play [[Silver Lining (Play)|Silver Lining]] opened at the Rose Theatre Kingston on 11 February 2017, before touring to Portsmouth, Oxford, Cambridge, Ipswich, Keswick, York, and Salford. It's about five elderly ladies and a young carer in a retirement home which is about to be flooded by a storm. It stars [[Rachel Davies]], [[Keziah Joseph]], Maggie McCarthy, [[Joanna Monro]], [[Sheila Reid]], and [[Amanda Walker]]. Toksvig's son, [[Theo Toksvig-Stewart]], made his professional stage debut in the play.{{cite web|title=Sandy Toksvig's Silver Lining|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/london-theatre/news/first-look-sandi-toksvig-silver-lining_42841.html|website=WhatsOnStage|accessdate=17 March 2017}} ===Writing=== She has written more than twenty fiction and non-fiction books for children and adults, starting in 1994 with ''Tales from the Norse's Mouth'', a fiction tale for children. In 1995, she sailed around the coast of Britain with [[John McCarthy (journalist)|John McCarthy]], who had been held hostage in [[Beirut]]. In 2003, she published ''Gladys Reunited: A Personal American Journey'', about her travels in the USA retracing her childhood. She writes regular columns for ''[[Good Housekeeping]]'', the ''[[Sunday Telegraph]]'' and ''[[The Lady (magazine)|The Lady]]''. In October 2008, she published ''Girls Are Best'', a [[women's history|history book for girls]].{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/sandi-toksvig-interview-the-history-woman-1-1148798|title=Sandi Toksvig interview: The history woman|work = The Scotsman|date=27 November 2008|accessdate=26 January 2016}} In 2009, her collected columns for ''The Sunday Telegraph'' were published in book form as ''The Chain of Curiosity''. In 2012, she published her latest book, ''Valentine Grey'', a historical novel set in the [[Boer War]].{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/fictionreviews/9558294/Valentine-Grey-by-Sandi-Toksvig-review.html|first=Lucy|last=Beresford|title=Valentine Grey by Sandi Toksvig: review |work = The Telegraph |date=27 September 2012 |accessdate=26 January 2016}} ===Television presenter=== In 2012–13 Toksvig presented ''[[1001 Things You Should Know]] for [[Channel 4]] daytime. Toksvig began presenting the revival edition of the daytime game show ''[[Fifteen-to-One]]'' in April 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2014-04-02/fifteen-to-one-returns-behind-the-scenes-with-sandi-toksvig|title=Fifteen to One returnos: behind the scenes with Sandi Toksvig|first=Emma|last=Daly|work=Radio Times|date=2 April 2014|accessdate=5 August 2015}} It is an hour long instead of the original half-hour edition presented by [[William G. Stewart]]. After two series had been broadcast, in June 2015, Channel 4 announced that a further three would be made, hosted by Toksvig.{{cite web|url=http://newsonnews.com/story/080615-620|title=Channel 4 Commits to Sandi Toksvig's Fifteen to One|website=News on News|date=8 June 2015|accessdate=5 August 2015}} Toksvig took over from [[Stephen Fry]] as host of ''[[QI]]''; she hosted the first episode of the show's series "N", which was broadcast on 21 October 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/2016/10/21/qi-sandi-toksvig-triumphs-in-her-first-appearance-as-host|title=QI Sandi Toksvig triumphs in her first appearance as host|website=The Telegraph|date=21 October 2016|accessdate=21 October 2016}} On 16 March 2017 she was announced as the new co-presenter of ''[[The Great British Bake Off]]'' on [[Channel 4]] alongside [[Noel Fielding]]. They replaced the previous hosts [[Sue Perkins]] and [[Mel Giedroyc]]. ==Politics and activism== Toksvig was part of [[Red Wedge]]'s comedy tour in the 1980s which actively supported the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] Party. She was later a high-profile political activist supporting the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]].{{cite web|url=http://liberalengland.blogspot.co.uk/2013/02/time-for-sandi-toksvig-to-give-up-news.html | title = Liberal England: Time for Sandi Toksvig to give up The News Quiz | website = liberalengland.blogspot.co.uk | publisher = Liberal England (blog) | accessdate=13 April 2015}}{{cite news | title = Screen stars join election race | work = [[BBC news]] | publisher = BBC | date = 25 May 2004 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3745121.stm | accessdate = 16 October 2008 | quote = "The celebrity bug has bitten the other major parties with the Lib Dems claiming the support of [...] broadcaster Sandi Toksvig." }} She both introduced frontbencher [[Menzies Campbell]] at the party's 2004 conference and was named as a possible parliamentary candidate.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} In 2003 she stood as a candidate in the election for the [[Chancellor]]ship of the [[University of Oxford]], supporting a campaign against [[Top-up fees|student fees]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/2793657.stm | title= Toksvig enters chancellor race |work=[[BBC News]] | publisher = BBC | date=24 February 2003|accessdate=16 March 2012}} She was defeated in the first round of voting, achieving 1,179 first-place votes out of about 8,000 cast.{{cite news | last = Curtis | first = Polly | title = Patten wins Oxford prize | url = http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/news/story/0,9830,915896,00.html?=rss | date = 17 March 2003 | work = [[The Guardian]] | accessdate = 24 May 2008| location = London, UK }} The election was won by [[Chris Patten]]. In 2011, some MPs urged [[Ofcom]] to investigate an "obscene joke" after Toksvig said on [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[The News Quiz]]'' that the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] had "put the 'N' into cuts" to child benefit.{{cite news | last = Blake | first = Heidi | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/8557822/BBC-in-decency-row-over-obscene-joke-by-Sandi-Toksvig.html | title = BBC in decency row over obscene joke by Sandi Toksvig | work = Daily Telegraph |accessdate=13 April 2015}} In 2012, she said in an interview that "I don't think there's a party that represents anything I believe in".{{cite news | last = Saner | first = Emine | title = Sandi Toksvig: 'I don't understand boredom' | work = The Guardian | date = 26 August 2012 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/aug/26/sandi-toksvig-interview | accessdate = 26 August 2012 }} Toksvig supports the charity and pressure group [[Liberty (pressure group)|Liberty]], hosting its 2012 awards ceremony.{{cite web | title = Liberty honours inspirational human rights leaders | url = http://www.liberty-human-rights.org.uk/media/press/2012/liberty-honours-inspirational-human-rights-leaders-in-an.php | website = liberty-human-rights.org.uk | date = 20 November 2012 | access-date = 26 April 2013 }} Toksvig attracted further criticism in 2015 for a joke on the subject of [[UK Independence Party|UKIP]] leader [[Nigel Farage]] having lost a testicle to cancer.{{cite web|url=https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2015/05/sandi-toksvig-makes-hitler-jibe-about-nigel-farage/|title=Sandi Toksvig makes Hitler jibe about Nigel Farage - Coffee House|date=26 May 2015|work=The Spectator}} She was appointed president of the [[Women of the Year Lunch]].{{cite web | title= The President | url= http://www.womenoftheyear.co.uk/the-board-council/the-presidents-message/ | author= | website= Women of the Year | accessdate= 7 May 2015 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150125075401/http://www.womenoftheyear.co.uk/the-board-council/the-presidents-message/ | archivedate= 25 January 2015 | df= dmy-all }} ===Women's Equality Party=== In April 2015, Toksvig chaired the first, informal, conference of a new political party, the [[Women's Equality Party]],{{cite news | last = Cocozza | first = Paula | title = Women's Equality party founders: 'It needed doing. So we said, "Let's do it"' | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/28/womens-equality-party-founders-it-needed-doing-so-we-said-lets-do-it-sandi-toksvig | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 28 August 2015 | accessdate = 21 September 2015 }}{{cite news | url = https://www.standard.co.uk/news/londoners-diary/londoners-diary-womens-party-is-ready-to-be-a-player-10189809.html | title = Londoner's Diary: Women's party is ready to be a player | work = [[London Evening Standard]] | date = 20 April 2015 | accessdate = 23 April 2015}} and she subsequently left her job as presenter of ''The News Quiz'' to become co-founder of the party. She later explained that she had decided that it was "not too late to fight the good fight, after all".{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/25/sandi-toksvig-trolls-womens-equality-party-bbc-abuse | title = Sandi Toksvig: trolls are already out over plans to form Women's Equality party | work = [[The Guardian]] | first = Jessica | last = Elgot | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 25 May 2015 | accessdate = 27 May 2015 }} In September the same year she announced the dates for a comedy tour to raise funds for the party.{{cite news | last = Duffy | first = Nick | title = Sandi Toksvig launches comedy tour to raise funds for new political party | url = https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2015/09/29/sandi-toksvig-launches-comedy-tour-to-raise-funds-for-new-political-party/ | work = [[PinkNews]] | publisher = | date = 29 September 2015 | access-date = 29 September 2015 }}{{cite news | last = Nixey | first = Catherine | title = Sandi Toksvig on swapping The News Quiz for the Women's Equality Party | url = http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/arts/article4570067.ece | work = [[The Times]] | publisher = [[News UK]] | subscription = yes | date = 29 September 2015 | access-date = 29 September 2015 }} The party's full set of policies were launched at [[Conway Hall]], 20 October 2015.{{cite web | title = Women's Equality Party announces first policies and campaigns | url = http://www.womensequality.org.uk/policy_launch_announcement | publisher = [[Women's Equality Party]] | date = 20 October 2015 | accessdate = 21 October 2015 }}{{cite news | last = Minter | first = Harriet | title = The Women's Equality Party launch is not a moment too soon | url = https://www.theguardian.com/women-in-leadership/2015/oct/21/the-womens-equality-party-launch-is-not-a-moment-too-soon | work = [[The Guardian]] | publisher = [[Guardian Media Group]] | date = 21 October 2015 | accessdate = 21 October 2015 }} ==Personal life== As an eleven-year-old, Toksvig was present with her father, a leading Danish foreign affairs journalist, at Mission Control in Houston, Texas during the first moon landing.QI XL. Series N;10. Nature/Nurture, BBC. UK Broadcast 30 Dec 2016Kerr, Alison (29 November 2008). "Sandi Toksvig interview: The history woman". The Scotsman. Retrieved 4 Jan 2017 In an appearance on BBC 1 show ''[[The TV That Made Me]]'', she stated she held the hand of Neil Armstrong's nervous secretary to calm the woman down during the final moments. She also revealed she had a lifetime fear of children's television puppet [[Basil Brush]], although, ironically, she had written a 2002 episode of ''[[The Basil Brush Show]]'' entitled "Molly Christmas". {{Quote box |quote=I wouldn’t care if they came from Tesco. I don’t care about the blood thing. They call me Mummy and I earned it. We love each other. You can’t do better than that. Lots of families don’t.|source=Toksvig commenting on her children in ''[[The Times]]''{{cite news | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/article1169426.ece | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110604214412/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/article1169426.ece | archivedate = 4 June 2011 | work = [[The Times]]|location=London | title = I have no secrets | date = 11 October 2002 | accessdate =16 March 2012 | first = Penny | last = Wark }}|width=25em |bgcolor=#FFFFF0 |quoted=true |salign=center }} Toksvig is the mother of two daughters and a son.{{cite news | url = http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/the_way_we_live/article3040129.ece | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110615194302/http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/the_way_we_live/article3040129.ece | archivedate = 15 June 2011 | work = [[The Times]] | title = A Life in the Day: Sandi Toksvig | last = Scott | first = Caroline | date=16 December 2007|location=London, UK|accessdate=16 March 2012}}{{cite news |url=http://thescotsman.scotsman.com/features/Sandi-Toksvig-interview-The-history.4737671.jp|title=Sandi Toksvig interview: The history woman|date=29 November 2008| work= [[The Scotsman]] |last=Kerr|first=Alison}} The children were carried by her then partner, Peta Stewart, from whom she separated in 1997, and were conceived through [[artificial insemination]] by [[Sperm donor|donor]] Christopher Lloyd-Pack,{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/comedy/article6942389.ece|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615084301/http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/comedy/article6942389.ece|archivedate=15 June 2011|title=Sandi Toksvig on her Christmas cracker|work =[[The Times]]|author=Ginny Dougary|date=5 December 2009|location=London, UK|accessdate=16 March 2012}} younger brother of the actor [[Roger Lloyd-Pack]].{{cite web|url=http://www.freebmd.org.uk/cgi/information.pl?cite=DgGjrBYSdR2j54Ol8PP2wg&scan=1|title=Index entry|accessdate=1 December 2013|work=FreeBMD|publisher=ONS}}{{cite web|author=Michael Coveney |url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/jan/16/roger-lloyd-pack |title=Roger Lloyd Pack obituary | Television & radio |publisher=The Guardian |date=2014-01-16 |accessdate=2016-08-07}} She lives on a [[houseboat]] in [[London Borough of Wandsworth|Wandsworth]]{{cite news | last = Rucki | first = Alexandra | url = http://www.wandsworthguardian.co.uk/news/10904614.Eighteen_people_make_New_Year_s_Honours_list_in_Wandsworth/?ref=nt | title=Eighteen people make New Year's Honours list in Wandsworth | work = Wandsworth Guardian |date=31 December 2013 |accessdate=31 December 2013 | location = London, UK}} with psychotherapist Debbie Toksvig, whom she joined in a [[civil partnership in the United Kingdom|civil partnership]] in 2007.{{cite news | last = Staff writer | url = http://www.itv.com/news/update/2014-03-29/sandi-toksvig-renews-wedding-vows-in-public-event | title = Sandi Toksvig renews wedding vows in public event | work = ITV news |publisher=ITV | date=29 March 2014 | accessdate=1 April 2014}} They renewed their vows on 29 March 2014, the day [[same-sex marriage in the United Kingdom|same-sex marriage]] was introduced in England and Wales,{{cite web | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/04/01/sandi-toksvig-gay-marriage-this-morning_n_5069139.html | title = Sandi Toksvig Praises New Gay Marriage Legislation On 'This Morning': 'It's About Love And Equality' | work = [[The Huffington Post|Huffington Post]] | date = 1 April 2014 | accessdate = 1 April 2014 }} and in December 2014, their civil partnership was converted into a marriage.{{cite news | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/sandi-toksvig-marries-partner-debbie-in-third-ceremony-tomorrow-i-will-love-her-even-more-9918231.html | title = Sandi Toksvig marries partner Debbie in third ceremony: 'Tomorrow, I will love her even more' | work = The Independent | date = 11 December 2014 | accessdate = 12 February 2015}} In 1994 the charity [[Save the Children]] dropped her services as compere of its 75th anniversary celebrations after she [[Coming out|came out]], but following a direct action protest by the [[Lesbian Avengers]],{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/lesbians-protest-over-charity-ban-1440911.html|title=Lesbians protest over charity ban|work=The Independent|date=5 October 1994|accessdate=16 March 2012}} the charity apologised.{{cite news|last=David|first=Smith|title=Comedian and actress Sandi Toksvig, a well-known face on the popular comedy improvisation TV show, ''Whose Line is it Anyway'', came out as a lesbian in the pages of the Sunday Times and Daily Mirror|work=Gay Times|issue=194|publisher=Millivres|date=November 1994|issn=0950-6101}} An atheist and [[secular humanism|humanist]], Toksvig is a patron of [[Humanists UK]].{{cite web | url = https://humanism.org.uk/about/our-people/patrons/sandi-toksvig/ | title = Sandi Toksvig | website = humanism.org.uk | publisher = [[Humanists UK]] | accessdate = 13 December 2017 }} In October 2012 she succeeded [[Sheila Hancock]] as Chancellor of the [[University of Portsmouth]].{{cite news | title = BBC News – Sandi Toksvig made Portsmouth University Chancellor | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-20141782 | work = [[BBC news]] | publisher = BBC | date = 31 October 2012 | access-date = 26 April 2013 }} Toksvig became a British citizen in 2013.{{cite news | url= http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/news/uk/article3843025.ece | title = Citizen Dane | first = Patrick |last=Kidd |work=The Times|date=15 August 2013|accessdate=5 August 2015}} Toksvig describes her "[[Received Pronunciation|posh]]" accent as being the result of a deliberate attempt to copy the voice of [[Celia Johnson]] in ''[[Brief Encounter]]'', after being ostracised at boarding school for having an American accent. ==Awards and honours== *1997 – The [[Grand Order of Water Rats]] Show Business Personality of the Year *2007 – Political Humorist of the Year at the [[Channel 4]] Political Awards{{cite web | title = Behind the scenes at the Channel Four Political Awards | url = http://admin.channel4.com/blogs/page/newsroom?entry=behind_the_scenes_at_the | publisher = Channel 4 Newsroom Blog | access-date = 16 May 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20120527004938/http://admin.channel4.com/blogs/page/newsroom?entry=behind_the_scenes_at_the | archivedate = 27 May 2012 | df = dmy-all }} and 2007 – Radio Broadcaster of the Year by the [[Broadcasting Press Guild]].{{cite web | url = http://www.broadcastingpressguild.org/?page_id=101 | title = 2007 Broadcasting Press Guild Awards | publisher = Broadcasting Press Guild | access-date = 16 May 2008 }} *2007 – Read it or Else Award from Coventry Inspiration Book Awards for ''Hitler's Canary'' *2008 – Broadcaster of the Year at the [[Stonewall Awards]] *2008 – [[Listening Books]] Award for the Spoken Word *2009 – [[Voice of the Listener & Viewer]] Award for Individual Contribution to Radio *2010 – Honorary [[Doctor of Letters]] [[University of Portsmouth]] *2012 – Honorary Doctor of Letters [[York St John University]] *2012 – Honorary Doctor of Letters [[University of Surrey]] *2012 – Honorary Fellowship [[Lucy Cavendish College, Cambridge]] *2013 – Voice of the Listener & Viewer Award for Excellence in Broadcasting (Roberts Radio Special Award) *2016 – Honorary Doctor of Letters [[University of Westminster]] *2016 – Honorary Fellowship [[Newnham College, Cambridge]] *2017 – CoScan (Confederation of Scandinavian Societies) International Award{{Cite web|url=http://www.coscan.org.uk/international-award/|title=CoScan – Confederation of Scandinavian Societies|last=|first=|date=|website=www.coscan.org.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-04-18}} *2018 – Honorary Doctor of Letters [[University of Leicester]]{{Cite web|url=https://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/press/for-journalists/graduation-ceremonies-1/summer-2018/honorands/sandi-toksvig-obe|title=Sandi Toksvig OBE — University of Leicester|last=pt91|website=www2.le.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-17}} ==Bibliography== ===Books for children=== * {{cite book|last=Toksvig|first=Sandi|title=Girls Are
